bibl.title: Letter from S.C. Mead to Robert M. O'Reilly, December 23, 1907

div1.p: Mead writes about work to increase the pensions for the families of Lazear and Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from S.C. Mead to Robert M. O'Reilly, December 23, 1907
div1.opener:
C O P Y.
New York, Dec. 23, 1907.
Brig-Genl. Robt. N. O'Reilly, Surgeon General, U.S.A.,
War Department,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
When in Washington last week I had the pleasure of speak-
ing to President Roosevelt relative to the Bills to be introduced in
Congress to provide increased pensions for the widows and children of
Dr. Lazear and Major Carroll.

The President stated to me, in response to my suggestion,
that he would be very happy to transmit to Congress, when the legis-
lation is pending, any specific recommendation in the shape of a
special report which you might prepare, urging favorable action on
the measures.

What I have in mind is a memorandum which would particu-
larly call attention to the work done by Major Carroll and Dr. Lazear
as members of the Yellow Fever Commission and the beneficial effect
thereof to the Army, and to every interest--in fact, to all citizens
of the United States.

The Association understands that Dr. A. S. v.Mansfelde,
Treasurer of the Nebraska Medical Association and Chairman of an
important Committee of the American Medical Association, is arranging
for the introduction of the two bills. In the House of Represen-
tatives both are to be presented by Congressman Hinahaw of Nebraska,
while in the Senate one will be introduced by Hon. Philander C. Knox
and the other by Hon. Charles Dick.

It is proposed to grant Mrs. Carroll a pension of $150.,
Brig-Genl. Robt. M. O'Reilly,
- 2 -
she having seven or eight children to support with no fixed income
of any kind, while Mrs. Lazear is to receive $125. a month.

I called at your office the other day in the hope of
personally laying the facts before you and in enlisting your further
valuable assistance by sending to the President a specific recommen-
dation for the increases in pension for Mrs. Lazear and Mrs. Carroll
at such time as I advise you is opportune in connection with the
status of the Bills.
A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Dr. Mansfelde.

With expressions of esteem, I remain, with the Compliments
of the Season,
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, ...(Signed)...S. C. Mead
Secretary,
THE MERCHANTS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW YORK.
